headline: [You want to add COVID-19 to headline to give relevancy + SEO keyword] [As COVID-19 carries into the new semester, Columbia does little to help struggling international students learn across different time zones.]
byline: By Jun Yi Zhang, Melissa Wang, Jessica Li and Michelle Xu Illustration by Brenda Huang

body.value: When the COVID-19 pandemic sent home Columbia’s undergraduate students, late nights, social isolation, and general exhaustion became the norm for those who returned to the opposite side of the world.
[impossible to accommodate all time zones]

Yet, even if course times are scheduled to be more accommodating to the majority of international students in Asia, this new set of course offerings would pose a challenge to those in another continent. With remote students scattered across more than 115 countries and a wide variation of time zones, schedules that work for those in China (GMT+8) are bound to be a problem for those in France (GMT+2).

International students recognize and understand the difficulties in accommodating all time zones; “there’s a limit to what they [the University] can do,” Whitney Deng, a Barnard first-year currently studying from Hong Kong noted.
[HOWEVER: shifting the convo to the most “popular” regions]

These students come from time zones that are at least 12 hours ahead of Eastern Standard Time, from places such as China, South Korea, Australia, and Singapore. Together, they make up approximately 44% of the international undergraduate population.

[visa & travel issues]

Returning to campus for the Fall 2020 semester was not an option for many of these students. On July 6, 2020, the Student and Exchange Visitor Program under the Trump administration banned international students from entering or remaining in the United States if they had a “fully online course load.” Although Trump revoked these exemptions eight days later following external pressure initially generated by a lawsuit submitted by Harvard and MIT, , international students continued to face barriers from entering the U.S.

While continuing students with fully online course loads were able to remain in the United States, nonimmigrant students in “New” or “Initial” status were still restricted from entering the country with a fully online course schedule for fall 2020.

The suspension of non-immigrant visa services in many embassies and consulates during the pandemic also meant that new international students and continuing students who needed visa renewals were unable to proceed with their visa application processes. Some embassies have slowly resumed non-immigrant services. However only those in Korea and the Philippines did so before Columbia’s fall semester began. Services in China remain suspended as of publication, and the Department of State is still unable to provide a specific date as to when each embassy will resume all services.

There is an extra challenge for those who possess functioning student visas in China: Presidential proclamations have suspended entry into the United States of noncitizens who have been to China anytime during the 14-days prior to their attempted entry. As such, Chinese international students must stop by a third country for at least 14 days before they are allowed into the United States.
[graphic: table]
[quick thing about physical repercussions]

Besides the myriad of travel restrictions international students face into the present, these students must also continue to cope with a disrupted circadian rhythms. With these changes come a host of potential health issues. Studies have shown that alterations in daily routine, such as modifying one’s sleep schedule in order to accommodate a time difference, can harm one’s physical and mental health. A broken sleep pattern can result in poor study efficiency as well as negative mood changes and fatigue.
[schools’ effort to help]

As the pandemic continued, Barnard’s Registrar’s Office and Columbia’s Core Office made efforts to help international students attend their classes. At the end of the fall 2020 semester, Barnard surveyed its students on which classes they intended to take in the upcoming spring semester and how important those classes were to them. Because the survey was released with the aim of providing feedback to Barnard when planning for the spring 2021 semester, many international students expected the college to accommodate their living in different time zones. However, for Katya Reichert, a Barnard first-year who spent the fall semester studying from the Philippines, the scheduled times of the top two courses that she indicated—Introduction to Art History II and Data Structures in Java—remained the same. “I don’t know if [the survey] was performative, or if not enough people chose the classes that I chose,” Reichert said.

Meanwhile, international students taking mandatory core classes also saw fruitless outcomes in the Core office’s effort to accommodate their time zones. In August, the Center for the Core Curriculum gave all students who were enrolled in Contemporary Civilization, Art Humanities, and/or Music Humanities the opportunity to petition for a new section if their current section met between 10 p.m. and 7 a.m. in their local time zone. However, when Columbia College sophomore Kevin Sun Park requested to switch out of his Contemporary Civilization section that was scheduled for 4 a.m. in Seoul, his petition was rejected by the Core Office.

“I never doubted that I wouldn’t be able to switch to another section,” explained Park. “Because I would have been taking classes from 4 a.m. to 6 a.m. In what kind of world would a university force me to do classes at that time?”
The School of Engineering and School of General Studies have not distributed surveys nor offered petition options.

[recs for asynchronous teaching across time zones]

Professors have also taken their own initiatives to ease the difficulty of learning in classes at unnatural hours, such as allowing asynchronous attendance, offering international-friendly office hours, and scheduling alternative exam times. Last Fall, Columbia’s Center for Teaching and Learning also published a guideline for asynchronous teaching across time zones.

However, the University still does not require professors to allow asynchronous attendance, meaning some students are still required to make the choice between academics, health, relationships, and extracurricular interests. [additional/optional note]

Considering President Bollinger’s announcement of a three-semester plan, Fall 2020 and Spring 2021 is no longer representative of the full course offerings for the 2020-21 school year. As of publication, Summer 2021 course offerings have not been updated for all departments. It is still unknown if the summer semester will be a chance for international students to have a healthier and more inclusive academic option amidst an ongoing pandemic.

Course codes ending from 1000 to 4000 were categorized as undergraduate courses; those without schedule information are unaccounted for. Data can be accessed here. Major requirement courses include those of the most popular 10 majors from each undergraduate college. Waffle chart time zones by country indicates that of capital city.
